metadata.case_name: Private Limited Company (Appellant) v. Income Tax Officer (Respondent)

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers, registered office in Bombay, resident and ordinarily resident in India.

Appellant's entire share capital beneficially owned by two British companies: P&O Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. and British India Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. (non-resident companies), whose business consists in plying ships for hire.
Under agreement with non-resident companies, appellant repairs their ships at cost and charges no profits.
Income-tax Officer assessed appellant under s.42(2) deeming profits at Rs.6,80,000 for 1943-44 (excess profits tax), Rs.4,67,559 for 1944-45 (income-tax), Rs.4,68,963 for 1945-46 (income-tax).
Orders of assessment made for income-tax 1944-45 and 1945-46, excess profits tax 1943-44 to 1945-46.
Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who confirmed orders on July 3, 1952.
Further appeal to Appellate Tribunal; Bench divided, President held s.42(2) inapplicable and set aside assessments on March 19, 1954.
On Department's application, Tribunal referred question: 'Whether on the facts and circumstances any income falls to be included in appellant's assessment under s.42(2)'.
Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ and Tendolkar J) held s.42(2) applicable on February 24, 1955.
Appellant obtained special leave under Art.136; proceedings concern income-tax 1944-45/1945-46 and excess profits tax 1943-44 to 1945-46.
Separate assessment for 1943-44 income-tax under s.34 made May 29, 1953, appeal pending before AAC, not subject of present proceedings.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts found the appellant is chargeable to tax under s.42(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.42(2) imposes charge only on business carried on by non-resident, not on resident appellant.
Condition for levy under s.42(2) not satisfied as non-residents do not carry on business with resident; non-residents only get ships repaired, which does not amount to carrying on business.

respondent_arguments.text: s.42(2) applicable to tax business of resident where due to close connection with non-resident, resident produces no or less than ordinary profits.

court_reasoning.text: Language of s.42(2) clear: taxes business of resident ('therefrom' refers to resident's business); rejects argument that it taxes non-resident's business based on 'derived therefrom', 'in the name of resident', 'deemed assessee'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'therefrom' refers only to business of resident.

court_reasoning.text: Non-resident companies carry on business with resident under s.42(2): special agreement for repairs at cost constitutes organised trading activities; 'business' broadly construed in fiscal statutes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dealings form concerted organised activities of business character.

court_reasoning.text: Rules 33/34 do not interpret s.42(2) as taxing non-resident's business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules have no effect on true interpretation of section.

holdings.text: Business subject to tax under s.42(2) is that of resident, not non-resident.
Non-resident companies carried on business with appellant resident company within s.42(2).
s.42(2) applicable; appellant liable to tax.

precedents_cited.relevance: Broad connotation of 'business' or 'trade' in fiscal statutes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Business' connotes real, substantial, systematic organised course of activity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Curimbhoy Ebrahim Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Business connection' in s.42(1) different from 'business' in s.4.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Continuity of business relationship constitutes business connection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

precedents_cited.relevance: Savings from arrangement not relevant as tax is on resident's deemed profits.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for charging tax on resident's deemed profits due to close connection with non-resident; reference and appeal provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Rules, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Modes for determining profits; do not alter interpretation of s.42(2).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court judgment; held s.42(2) applicable to appellant's business due to close connection with non-resident companies, confirming assessments to income-tax and excess profits tax.

key_quotes.text: "The language of the enactment imposing the charge is too plain to admit of any doubt. ... it is this business therefore that is the subject of the charge under s.42(2)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies tax is on resident's business.

key_quotes.text: "The word business is ... one of wide import and in fiscal statutes, it must be construed in a broad rather than a restricted sense."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "a non-resident should be held to carry on business with a resident, if the dealings between them form concerted and organised activities of a business character."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for non-resident carrying on business with resident.
